definitions: Resistance that changes through the range of motion to better match the lifter’s force capability.
A loading approach where external resistance increases or decreases as leverage changes.
Typically achieved with bands or chains so the lift is heavier where you’re stronger.
A method to “accommodate” the strength curve and reduce the mismatch of constant load.
Variable loading that can reduce deceleration near lockout and promote intent to move fast.
A strategy that alters effective resistance across ROM rather than keeping it constant.
In practice: lighter at the weakest point, heavier near the strongest point (often).
Band/chain-based loading used to align resistance with torque capacity across a lift.
Training methods or implements used instead of traditional free weights or machines.
Substitute approaches for achieving a similar training goal when standard tools aren’t ideal.
Nonstandard modalities used to train strength, power, conditioning, or movement quality.
Different equipment or setups chosen to manage constraints (injury, space, variety, specificity).
A category that includes strongman implements, sleds, bands, kettlebells, bodyweight work, etc.
Ways to train the same quality using different external resistance patterns or environments.
A programming option to keep the stimulus while changing the exercise/tool.
Any non-primary training approach used as a replacement or complement to core lifts.
The trunk muscles including abdominals, spinal extensors, diaphragm, and pelvic floor.
Muscles that contribute to spinal and pelvic stability and pressure regulation.
The structural and muscular system supporting the spine during movement and load transfer.
Includes deep stabilizers and global movers of the trunk (not just the “abs”).
Musculature that helps resist unwanted trunk motion (flexion, extension, rotation, shear).
The body’s central stabilizing region used for force transmission between upper and lower body.
A functional unit supporting posture, breathing mechanics, and bracing.
Trunk muscles responsible for stiffness and stability under load.
A knee ligament that resists anterior tibial translation and contributes to rotational stability.
Primary restraint against the tibia sliding forward relative to the femur.
A key stabilizer for cutting, pivoting, deceleration, and landing mechanics.
Ligament that helps control knee internal rotation and valgus collapse under load.
A structure commonly injured during noncontact planting/cutting with poor control.
Stabilizer affected by high anterior shear and rotational forces at the knee.
A ligament connecting femur to tibia that limits forward tibial movement.
A major passive stabilizer supporting knee joint integrity in sport movements.
Bones of the head, vertebral column, ribs, and sternum.
The skeleton forming the body’s central axis (skull + spine + thoracic cage).
Framework supporting posture and protecting the brain, spinal cord, and thoracic organs.
The central skeletal system to which the appendicular skeleton attaches.
Includes skull, vertebrae, ribs, and sternum.
The midline skeleton responsible for structural support and protection.
Core bony structures of the trunk and head.
Central-axis bones (not the limbs).
Performance or strength differences between the left and right sides of the body.
Side-to-side discrepancies in force, power, mobility, stability, or coordination.
Imbalances that may affect movement efficiency and injury risk if large or persistent.
Differences seen in unilateral tests (e.g., single-leg jump, split squat, single-arm press).
Neuromuscular or structural differences between limbs.
A mismatch in capacity or control from one side of the body to the other.
Asymmetric outputs in bilateral tasks or measured unilaterally.
Unequal left vs right performance characteristics.
When force from a bilateral effort is less than the sum of unilateral efforts.
A phenomenon where two-limb performance is lower than the combined one-limb performances.
Often observed when comparing bilateral vs unilateral jumps or strength tests.
A neuromuscular coordination/activation limitation during simultaneous limb contraction.
Indicates reduced total output when both limbs work together versus separately.
Bilateral task underperforms relative to the unilateral sum.
A commonly discussed concept supporting unilateral training in some contexts.
Two-leg/two-arm output < (left alone + right alone).
When bilateral force production exceeds the sum of unilateral outputs.
A phenomenon where two-limb performance is greater than (left alone + right alone).
Suggests synergy or improved stability/coordination during bilateral efforts.
Bilateral task outperforms the combined unilateral results.
Can appear in certain lifts where trunk stability and interlimb coordination boost output.
Enhanced force output during simultaneous limb contraction.
A bilateral advantage compared with unilateral sum.
Two-limb output > (left alone + right alone).
Training that uses the athlete’s body mass as the primary resistance.
Exercises where external load is minimal and the body provides the resistance.
Movements like push-ups, pull-ups, squats, lunges, dips, and planks.
A mode emphasizing relative strength, control, and movement quality.
A practical approach requiring little equipment; load is manipulated via leverage and tempo.
Resistance training where the athlete is the implement.
Self-resisted training primarily using body mass and gravity.
Exercises that challenge strength through body positioning and range of motion.
Variable-resistance devices attached to a barbell that increase load as the bar rises.
A method of accommodating resistance: more chain lifts off the floor through the concentric.
A tool that makes the top of the lift heavier than the bottom.
A way to change effective load across ROM without changing plates.
Chain loading that can reduce deceleration near lockout and increase intent.
A strongman/powerlifting tool used for progressive resistance within a rep.
Weighted chains used to alter resistance profile in barbell lifts.
A variable loading method where resistance increases with bar height.
Resistance that stays the same across the range of motion (e.g., free weights).
A loading condition where external load does not change as joint angles change.
A fixed-mass resistance (plates/dumbbells) that doesn’t “accommodate” leverage changes.
The standard resistance profile for most barbell and dumbbell lifts.
Resistance that can feel harder at weak joint angles and easier at strong angles.
A constant-weight stimulus where torque demands change mainly due to biomechanics.
Uniform external load throughout a rep.
Non-variable load as opposed to bands/chains.
Anatomical structures that stabilize the spine and pelvis during movement.
The trunk region and its stabilizers that resist unwanted motion and transfer force.
A functional system that supports posture, bracing, and efficient force transmission.
Structures and muscles that control spinal position under load.
The stabilizing center linking upper and lower extremity movement.
Trunk stability capacity, not just abdominal strength.
The region responsible for controlling the torso and pelvis in sport and lifting.
Stability system enabling efficient movement and load transfer.
A loaded carry where the athlete walks holding weights in each hand.
A strongman-style carry developing grip, trunk stiffness, and whole-body work capacity.
A gait-based strength exercise emphasizing postural control under load.
A carry that challenges lateral trunk stability and shoulder/upper back endurance.
Walking with heavy implements while maintaining neutral spine and steady steps.
An exercise integrating grip strength, bracing, and locomotion.
A bilateral carry with external load held at the sides.
Loaded walking with implements in both hands.
Free weight exercises performed with the feet on the ground.
Lifts that require force transfer through the kinetic chain into the ground.
Exercises emphasizing whole-body stabilization and coordinated force production.
Movements like squats, deadlifts, presses (standing), Olympic lift derivatives, etc.
Standing or foot-supported free-weight movements requiring balance and posture control.
Exercises where the athlete must stabilize the load without external guidance.
Ground-contact lifts integrating lower body, trunk, and upper body coordination.
Free-weight movements with ground reaction force involvement.
Exercises designed to primarily move at one joint and target one main muscle group.
Single-joint movements emphasizing a specific muscle rather than total-body coordination.
Accessory work used to add volume with lower systemic fatigue than big compound lifts.
Exercises like leg extensions, hamstring curls, biceps curls, triceps pressdowns.
Movements that reduce demands on stabilizers compared to multi-joint lifts.
Exercises that concentrate stress on a limited set of muscles.
A training category often used for hypertrophy, rehab, or weak-point targeting.
Single-joint accessory training.
Handled weights used for ballistic and strength exercises.
A cast-iron/steel implement with an offset center of mass due to the handle.
Tools commonly used for swings, cleans, snatches, carries, and presses.
Implements enabling power-endurance and hip hinge patterning via ballistic work.
A nontraditional weight that challenges grip and trunk stability with dynamic movement.
A resistance tool often used for cyclic ballistic training and conditioning.
Handle-based weight that facilitates swing-based power training.
An implement used for strength and ballistic exercises with unique leverage.
Strongman pressing/carrying implements that challenge grip and trunk stability.
A large cylindrical implement used for log clean and press variations.
A nontraditional tool that alters pressing mechanics compared with a barbell.
An implement commonly used in strongman to train overhead strength and bracing.
A thick-grip, awkward-object implement increasing stability demands.
Pressing/carrying equipment that emphasizes trunk stiffness and upper-body power.
A strongman tool requiring different rack/press positions than a standard bar.
Awkward implement used for strength, power, and work capacity.
Training performed on machines that guide movement and provide external stabilization.
Resistance exercises where the machine constrains the movement path.
A mode that can reduce balance/stabilizer demands and target muscles more directly.
Equipment-based resistance training with fixed or semi-fixed lever/track systems.
Often useful for hypertrophy, beginners, rehab, or managing fatigue and technique limits.
Machine-guided lifting where the implement provides support and direction.
External stabilization allowing focus on prime movers.
Resistance training using selectorized or plate-loaded machines.
Recruitment and firing of motor units within a muscle.
The process of turning muscle fibers on via neural input to produce force.
A description of neural drive to a muscle during a movement.
How strongly and how many motor units are engaged at a given moment.
A factor influenced by intent, technique, fatigue, and training status.
Neural stimulation leading to muscle tension development.
Level of motor unit recruitment and rate coding within a muscle.
The muscle’s neural “on” signal during contraction.
Training equipment other than standard barbells, dumbbells, or machines.
Implements that change load handling, leverage, or stability compared to conventional tools.
Tools such as sandbags, logs, sleds, stones, kettlebells, bands, chains, etc.
Equipment often used to add variety, specificity, or novel stability demands.
A category including awkward objects and variable-resistance devices.
Alternative tools used to target strength, power, grip, and trunk control.
Nonstandard resistance tools used for performance training.
Implements outside the typical commercial gym defaults.
An elastic device that provides variable resistance that increases as it stretches.
A tool used for accommodating resistance, assistance, warm-ups, and rehab.
Elastic resistance that changes tension across the range of motion.
A portable implement used to alter resistance profiles or reduce load at weak points.
A method to load speed-strength while maintaining intent to accelerate.
Elastic training tool where force rises with elongation.
Band tension used to modify a lift’s difficulty throughout ROM.
Variable-tension resistance implement.
The most mechanically difficult portion of a lift where velocity decreases or stalls.
The range in which leverage is poorest and force demand is highest relative to capacity.
A common failure zone in a lift (e.g., off the chest in bench, out of the hole in squat).
The point where bar speed drops sharply and technique often degrades.
A limiting region that can be targeted with partials, pauses, or accommodating resistance.
The hardest ROM segment due to biomechanics and/or weak muscle contribution.
A lift’s “bottleneck” position.
Momentary slowdown region indicating mechanical disadvantage.
Training using nontraditional implements to develop strength, power, and work capacity.
A style emphasizing awkward-object handling, carries, pulls, and presses.
Training that builds total-body strength, grip, trunk stiffness, and conditioning.
Implements include logs, stones, sleds, yokes, farmer carries, sandbags, etc.
A method that often blends strength and conditioning under heavy load.
Performance training focused on moving heavy objects in diverse tasks.
A modality that increases stability and bracing demands due to irregular implements.
Nontraditional strength training with high carry/drag/press emphasis.
Forced exhalation against a closed airway (closed glottis).
A bracing breath that increases intra-abdominal pressure to stabilize the trunk.
A technique used during heavy lifts to stiffen the torso and support the spine.
Breath-hold and brace method improving spinal stability under load.
A pressure-building maneuver that can transiently affect blood pressure.
A lifting breath strategy: inhale, brace, hold through the hardest portion, then exhale.
A trunk-stability breathing technique used in squats, deadlifts, presses.
Respiratory maneuver to increase trunk rigidity during high-force efforts.
Resistance that changes throughout the range of motion rather than staying constant.
Loading that varies with joint angle, bar position, or implement tension (bands/chains).
A method used to better match resistance to the lifter’s strength curve.
Non-constant external resistance applied within a rep.
Band and chain loading are common examples.
A strategy that can reduce deceleration and encourage acceleration intent.
Resistance that increases or decreases during movement.
Any setup where external load is ROM-dependent.
